Status of the <sup>36</sup>Cl AMS system at the University of Tsukuba
Activation of gold by the neutrons from the JCO accident

description.en: Gold-198 induced by the JCO criticality accident of 30 September 1999 was measured to evaluate the environmental impact of the neutrons derived from the accident. The number of (198)AU atoms at about 370 m from the JCO site was estimated to be as high as 6 x 10(6) atoms g(-1) The influence of the accident was observed up to 1400 m. The general trend of the neutron fluence as a function of distance from the site was well reproduced by theoretical calculations. (C) 2000 Elsevier Science Ltd. All rights reserved.

paper_title.ja: Passive gamma-ray spectrometry for the determination of fission events in the JCO criticality accident '99 in Tokai.
paper_title.en: Passive gamma-ray spectrometry for the determination of total fission events in the JCO criticality accident '99 in Tokai
The JCO criticality accident at Tokai-mura, Japan: an overview of the sampling campaign and preliminary results

description.en: A criticality accident occurred on September 30, 1999 at the uranium conversion facility of the JCO Company Ltd. in Tokai-mura, Japan. A collaborating scientific investigation team was organized in two groups, the first to carry out research on the environmental impact (the environmental research group) and the second to assess the radiation effects on residents (the biological research group). This report concerns only the activities of the environmental research group. Four investigative teams were sent on different dates to the accident site and its vicinity to collect samples. About 400 samples were collected and subjected to analysis. An outline of the sampling campaign is presented here along with a brief chronology of the accident and the preliminary key results obtained by the independent research group are summarised in this Special Issue of the Journal of Environmental Radioactivity. (C) 2000 Elsevier Science Ltd. All rights reserved.

paper_title.en: Development of a gas Delta E-position sensitive E detector for AMS studies

description.en: A gas Delta E-position sensitive E counter telescope for accelerator mass spectrometry (AA;IS) study has been developed, The detector has been tested with both Americium alpha and Cl-36 measurements. The total energy resolution and the position resolution are 4.5% and 2 mm, respectively, The strong background in AMS experiments can be suppressed by the combination of CIE and position information. Cl-36 can be distinguished from both Cl-35 and S-36 backgrounds.
